awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Project: Workshops and Learning Communities for Physics and Astronomy Faculty
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative project involving the American Association of Physics Teachers (Award DUE-1431638), Brigham Young University (Award DUE-1431454), the University of Maryland at College Park (Award DUE-1431681), and the University of Colorado at Boulder (Award DUE-1431779).

Most new college and university STEM faculty members begin their first teaching assignments with little or no experience with methods of effective pedagogy. Consequently, both they and their students are often frustrated when the students do not seem to learn what the faculty members think they are teaching. To address this problem in physics and astronomy, the American Association of Physics Teachers, the American Astronomical Society, and the American Physical Society propose to continue a successful series of Physics and Astronomy Faculty Workshops focusing on effective pedagogy, building on what has been learned during the previous series of workshops. During the course of the new five-year project, the workshops will work with about 900 four-year college and university faculty members (about 50% of the new tenure-track hires in physics and astronomy in the United States), who collectively teach more than 100,000 students each year.

Three new components will be added to the program of workshops:  (1) a permanent set of Experienced Faculty Workshops aimed at more senior faculty members; (2) a series of virtual Faculty Learning Communities (FLCs), which will provide coaching and feedback for the workshop participants as they implement interactive-engagement teaching methods; and (3) a research program focusing on the most effective ways to implement the FLCs and developing a more systematic understanding of the workshops themselves. Items (2) and (3) will directly address the "implementation dip" that occurs for faculty considering the use of new pedagogy. The dip has been documented in almost all STEM faculty workshops. Although the current physics and astronomy workshops have been successful in developing knowledge about effective pedagogy and the evidence for its effectiveness, and in inspiring the participants to implement those pedagogies, the evaluations also show that the faculty members are not always persistent in implementing those pedagogies. The new project is designed to enhance the implementation of what the participants learn in the workshops and to add to the knowledge base of what constitutes effective pedagogical professional development for physics and astronomy faculty. The same methods should be broadly applicable to faculty members in other STEM disciplines.

This project is being jointly funded by four NSF programs:
* Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE), Division of Undergraduate Education, Directorate for Education and Human Resources;
* Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP), Division of Human Resource Development, Directorate for Education and Human Resources;
* Education and Interdisciplinary Research (EIR), Division of Physics, Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences; and
* Education and Special Programs (ESP), Division of Astronomical Sciences, Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
The Physics and Astronomy New Faculty Workshops supported by this project provided professional development in research-based teaching methods and the evidence for their effectiveness in enhancing student learning to 1125 physics and astronomy faculty members during its eight-year funding period (with two no-cost extensions). Those faculty members constitute about 40% of the new tenure-tracks hires in physics and astronomy across the U.S and came from about 600 colleges and universities, about 80% of the 750 institutions that offer bachelor's degrees in physics.  Based on the conservative estimate that each faculty member teaches about 100 students every year, the project has had an impact on more than 100,000 students per year.  In the last three years of the project, the percentage of New Faculty Workshop participants identifying as female increased to about 37%, far above the 20% of new PhDs in physics and astronomy earned by female faculty. About 20% of the participants came from minority-serving institutions, in line with the 19% of physics-degree-granting institutions which are minority-serving institutions.

The Intellectual Merit of the project lies in its use of use of teaching methods whose effectiveness has been established by decades of physics education research and in its team of presenters who are recognized for their contributions to both physics education and physics research.  Over the duration of the funding period, the workshops including substantially more explicit attention to diversity, equity, and inclusion issues.  During the covid-pandemic, the program switched to three online workshops each drawing about 120 participants, substantially larger the typical 70 participants for each of the in-person workshops, than the active participation in the online sessions varied widely with time.  The program also offered its July 2022 workshop in Los Angeles, the first such offering outside the Washington, DC area.  Although there was a slight increase in the number of participants from Southern California, the geographic distribution of participants’ home institution was not noticeably different from the DC area workshops.  The project’s Broader Impacts lie in the widespread engagement of college and university faculty members across the country and an enhanced use of research-based active learning pedagogy by the participants.

The results of an external evaluation of the project indicate that the program is extremely effective in building the participants' knowledge of evidence- based teaching methods and having them implement those methods in their classes. 

In addition to the New Faculty Workshops, the project hosted one workshop for Experienced Faculty Members in March 2016 and a brief workshop for Historically Black Colleges and Universities physics faculty at the National Society of Black Physicists meeting in October 2016.  Both workshops were attractive to department leaders such as department chairs and associate chairs for undergraduate studies as well as senior faculty members who wanted to become familiar with research-based interactive engagement teaching methods.
